item.title: Technical
item.description: Python lead developer of cbayes contributor and researcher on BET extensive experience generating technical notebooks with varying levels of interactivity familiarity with JupyterHub, JupyterLab deep interest in reproducible open science and removing all friction towards such an end Matlab first language, used for countless projects. I have since moved away from it in favor of open-source alternatives. Git familiarity with basic repository management have used Github, Bitbucket, and Gitlab I use it to track changes to nearly all the work I do LaTeX preferred document-generation language (pdfs) basic familiarity with publishing formatting for large documents extensive experience writing technical reports Terminal (Bash/Shell) Almost everything I do with respect to programming happens in a bash shell Much of my work is done remotely through ssh Vim My preferred text-editor and distraction-free organizational tool Adobe Suite experienced in Photoshop for general graphic design (posters, figures) familiar with Illustrator Microsoft Suite comfortable in Excel, though I prefer not to use it for anything related to analyzing data.

item.title: Research
item.description: Solving problems of paramount importance to humanity. Showing, not telling the limitless potential of applied mathematics.

item.title: Publications
item.description: Group-level events are catalysts in the evolution of cooperation Journal of Theoretical Biology 410 (2016) pp. 125-136 (Elsevier), available on Science Direct My co-author made it available FOR FREE on his website

item.title: A Rocky Opportunity
item.description: Dr. Kyle Mandli’s presentation at a minisymposium at the 2018 SIAM Annual Meeting began differently than most. Shaky footage from an antiquated cellphone filled the first slide and was captioned with an ominous harbinger for the rest of the talk: “Can we model this?” On screen the audience is witness to a rocky river basin bordered by lush jungle. In the distance a faint mist is visible, and the footage slowly zooms in towards it.

item.title: Python
item.description: My favorite programming language. Things I Have Written How to set up anaconda - gists.github.com/mpilosov/ String Formatting (making titles out of lowercase strings) Plotting Quick Marginal Distribution Visualization with Seaborn Piecewise-defined functions and 3D Matplotlib Plots Drawing Lines atop scatterplots Plotting a circle Three-Dimensional Projections (with Linear Algebra) Things Others Have Written Learning Pandas (like R… for Python) Scraping Webpages with Pandas Using *args and **kwargs in Python

item.title: Writing Resources
item.description: Markdown The comprehensive guide in which I ctrl+F almost everything Someone made a good walkthrough that I often refer to Cheat Sheet from Assemble.io On Writing Jordan B Peterson\’s Guide to Writing an Essay is remarkably helpful when dealing with writers block. Most of the advice generalizes well beyond topics in the humanities.

item.title: General Resources
item.description: My Gists on Github are a good place to see what I have found useful to write down for future reference. The use of sines and cosines in programming (or, how to make pretty pictures!) Git (version control) The guide everyone uses to get started Stop Asking for Password: git config --global credential.helper 'cache --timeout 28800' And to forget: git credential-cache exit or, if you’re on OSX: git config --system --unset credential.

item.title: Michael Pilosov
item.description: MS, Applied Mathematics Mathematics of Sciences and Engineering PhD Candidate Uncertainty Quantification digital résumé I work on collecting useful information from scientific experiments, describing and minimizing uncertainty. After graduation, I will work on diverse problems in a variety of fields that serve a humanitarian purpose. If you are curious about whether you have a problem that can benefit from risk assessment or experimental design, let’s talk about how.

item.title: More Information About What I Do
item.description: I work in the field of Uncertainty Quantification, specifically on inverse problems (usually with models involving physics). I am concerned about how experimental data impacts predictions. Sometimes that means getting the most out of what limited data is available. Other times it involves designing the experiment so that each measurement is as informative as possible. Not all data are equally useful. I help decide what is worth measuring. The applications of my academic research are numerous.
